author: Grimms
text: Once upon a time there was a dear little girl who was loved by everyone who looked at her, but most of all by her grandmother, and there was nothing that she would not have given to the child.

author: Grimms
text: Once she gave her a little cap of red velvet, which suited her so well that she would never wear anything else; so she was always called "Little RedCap."

author: Grimms
text: One day her mother said to her: "Come, Little Red-Cap, here is a piece of cake and a bottle of wine; take them to your grandmother, she is ill and weak, and they will do her good.

author: Grimms
text: Set out before it gets hot, and when you are going, walk nicely and quietly and do not run off the path, or you may fall and break the bottle, and then your grandmother will get nothing; and when you go into her room, don"t forget to say, "Good morning", and don"t peep into every corner before you do it."

author: Grimms
text: "I will take great care," said Little Red-Cap to her mother, and gave her hand on it.

author: Grimms
text: The grandmother lived out in the wood, half a league from the village, and just as Little Red-Cap entered the wood, a wolf met her.

author: Grimms
text: Red-Cap did not know what a wicked creature he was, and was not at all afraid of him.

author: Grimms
text: "Good day, Little Red-Cap," said he.

author: Grimms
text: "Thank you kindly, wolf."

author: Grimms
text: "Whither away so early, Little Red-Cap?"

author: Grimms
text: "To my grandmother"s."

author: Grimms
text: "What have you got in your apron?"

author: Grimms
text: "Cake and wine; yesterday was baking-day, so poor sick grandmother is to have something good, to make her stronger."

author: Grimms
text: "Where does your grandmother live, Little Red-Cap?"

author: Grimms
text: "A good quarter of a league farther on in the wood; her house stands under the three large oak-trees, the nut-trees are just below; you surely must know it," replied Little Red-Cap.

author: Grimms
text: The wolf thought to himself: "What a tender young creature! what a nice plump mouthful--she will be better to eat than the old woman.

author: Grimms
text: I must act craftily, so as to catch both."

author: Grimms
text: So he walked for a short time by the side of Little Red-Cap, and then he said: "See, Little Red-Cap, how pretty the flowers are about here--why do you not look round?

author: Grimms
text: I believe, too, that you do not hear how sweetly the little birds are singing; you walk gravely along as if you were going to school, while everything else out here in the wood is merry."

author: Grimms
text: Little Red-Cap raised her eyes, and when she saw the sunbeams dancing here and there through the trees, and pretty flowers growing everywhere, she thought: "Suppose I take grandmother a fresh nosegay; that would please her too.

author: Grimms
text: It is so early in the day that I shall still get there in good time"; and so she ran from the path into the wood to look for flowers.

author: Grimms
text: And whenever she had picked one, she fancied that she saw a still prettier one farther on, and ran after it, and so got deeper and deeper into the wood.

author: Grimms
text: Meanwhile the wolf ran straight to the grandmother"s house and knocked at the door.

author: Grimms
text: "Who is there?"

author: Grimms
text: "Little Red-Cap," replied the wolf.

author: Grimms
text: "She is bringing cake and wine; open the door."

author: Grimms
text: "Lift the latch," called out the grandmother, "I am too weak, and cannot get up."

author: Grimms
text: The wolf lifted the latch, the door sprang open, and without saying a word he went straight to the grandmother"s bed, and devoured her.

author: Grimms
text: Then he put on her clothes, dressed himself in her cap laid himself in bed and drew the curtains.

author: Grimms
text: Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.

author: Grimms
text: She was surprised to find the cottage-door standing open, and when she went into the room, she had such a strange feeling that she said to herself: "Oh dear! how uneasy I feel today, and at other times I like being with grandmother so much."

author: Grimms
text: She called out: "Good morning," but received no answer; so she went to the bed and drew back the curtains.

author: Grimms
text: There lay her grandmother with her cap pulled far over her face, and looking very strange.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh! grandmother," she said, "what big ears you have!"

author: Grimms
text: "The better to hear you with, my child," was the reply.

author: Grimms
text: "But, grandmother, what big eyes you have!" she said.

author: Grimms
text: "The better to see you with, my dear."

author: Grimms
text: "But, grandmother, what large hands you have!"

author: Grimms
text: "The better to hug you with."

author: Grimms
text: "Oh! but, grandmother, what a terrible big mouth you have!"

author: Grimms
text: "The better to eat you with!"

author: Grimms
text: And scarcely had the wolf said this, than with one bound he was out of bed and swallowed up Red-Cap.

author: Grimms
text: When the wolf had appeased his appetite, he lay down again in the bed, fell asleep and began to snore very loud.

author: Grimms
text: The huntsman was just passing the house, and thought to himself: "How the old woman is snoring!

author: Grimms
text: I must just see if she wants anything."

author: Grimms
text: So he went into the room, and when he came to the bed, he saw that the wolf was lying in it.

author: Grimms
text: "Do I find you here, you old sinner!" said he.

author: Grimms
text: "I have long sought you!"

author: Grimms
text: Then just as he was going to fire at him, it occurred to him that the wolf might have devoured the grandmother, and that she might still be saved, so he did not fire, but took a pair of scissors, and began to cut open the stomach of the sleeping wolf.

author: Grimms
text: When he had made two snips, he saw the little Red-Cap shining, and then he made two snips more, and the little girl sprang out, crying: "Ah, how frightened I have been!

author: Grimms
text: How dark it was inside the wolf"; and after that the aged grandmother came out alive also, but scarcely able to breathe.

author: Grimms
text: Red-Cap, however, quickly fetched great stones with which they filled the wolf"s belly, and when he awoke, he wanted to run away, but the stones were so heavy that he collapsed at once, and fell dead.

author: Grimms
text: Then all three were delighted.

author: Grimms
text: The huntsman drew off the wolf"s skin and went home with it; the grandmother ate the cake and drank the wine which Red-Cap had brought, and revived, but Red-Cap thought to herself: "As long as I live, I will never by myself leave the path, to run into the wood, when my mother has forbidden me to do so."

author: Grimms
text: It also related that once when Red-Cap was again taking cakes to the old grandmother, another wolf spoke to her, and tried to entice her from the path.

author: Grimms
text: Red-Cap, however, was on her guard, and went straight forward on her way, and told her grandmother that she had met the wolf, and that he had said "good morning" to her, but with such a wicked look in his eyes, that if they had not been on the public road she was certain he would have eaten her up.

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said the grandmother, "we will shut the door, that he may not come in."

author: Grimms
text: Soon afterwards the wolf knocked, and cried: "Open the door, grandmother, I am Little Red-Cap, and am bringing you some cakes."

author: Grimms
text: But they did not speak, or open the door, so the grey-beard stole twice or thrice round the house, and at last jumped on the roof, intending to wait until Red-Cap went home in the evening, and then to steal after her and devour her in the darkness.

author: Grimms
text: But the grandmother saw what was in his thoughts.

author: Grimms
text: In front of the house was a great stone trough, so she said to the child: "Take the pail, Red-Cap; I made some sausages yesterday, so carry the water in which I boiled them to the trough."

author: Grimms
text: Red-Cap carried until the great trough was quite full.

author: Grimms
text: Then the smell of the sausages reached the wolf, and he sniffed and peeped down, and at last stretched out his neck so far that he could no longer keep his footing and began to slip, and slipped down from the roof straight into the great trough, and was drowned.

author: Grimms
text: But Red-Cap went joyously home, and no one ever did anything to harm her again.
